<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_from_data:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_data (size_t size,
                               void *data,
                               int must_free,
                               int must_copy)
{
  enum MHD_ResponseMemoryMode mode;

  if (0 != must_copy)
    mode = MHD_RESPMEM_MUST_COPY;
  else if (0 != must_free)
    mode = MHD_RESPMEM_MUST_FREE;
  else
    mode = MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT;

  return MHD_create_response_from_buffer (size, data, mode);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_data (size_t size,
                               void *data,
                               int must_free,
                               int must_copy)
explanation: The only candidate for a compiler-specific language extension in this snippet is the identifier _MHD_EXTERN, which is a macro that commonly expands to compiler-specific storage-class or attribute tokens (for example __declspec(...) on MSVC or __attribute__(...) / visibility pragmas on GCC/Clang). That expansion — if it contains compiler-specific keywords — would be a language extension and should be investigated. All other constructs in the function are standard C: size_t, void *, int parameter types, enum usage, conditional statements, and the return of a function call. There are no inline assembly blocks, GCC/Clang attributes written directly in this code, nested functions, statement expressions, typeof, variable-length arrays, or other explicit compiler extensions visible here, so they do not require investigation from the Rule 1.2 perspective.
